div.head: INTRODUCTION.
div.p: THAT the following oration may lead to no mi≈øconception of the opinion I entertain, re≈øpecting the actual origin of our late epidemics, I beg leave to introduce it to the notice of my fellow-citizens, by a few preliminary remarks.

I. I do not believe that, either, in the years ninety three, ninety ≈øeven, or ninety eight, the American pe≈øtilence was exclu≈øively of dome≈øtic origin. of the United States. Nor is it a matter of the ≈ømalle≈øt import, from what quarter of the globe the≈øe cargoes come. Provided, they be of a putrefiable nature, and arrive in our ports, during the inten≈øity of our ≈øummer heats, (but, particularly, between the middle of July and la≈øt of September,) it is wholly immaterial whether they be the native productions of Europe, of A≈øia, of Africa, or of the We≈øt India I≈ølands. And it is equally immaterial, from which of the≈øe places they are immediately imported. The ≈øu≈øpen≈øion, therefore, of commercial intercour≈øe, during certain months in the year, with the We≈øt India I≈ølands alone, would be a mea≈øure wholly inadequate to the prevention of this di≈øea≈øe. Were ≈øuch ≈øu≈øpen≈øion adopted by the Government of the Union, it ≈øhould, unque≈øtionably, extend to all parts of the globe, from which putrefiable cargoes may be imported. But ≈øuch an impolitic mea≈øure, ≈øugge≈øts at once ≈øufficient cau≈øe for its immediate rejection, as it is evidently pregnant with nothing le≈øs than ab≈øolute ruin to the commerce of our country.

II. I have not found ≈øufficient cau≈øe to believe, that, without the co-operation of foul air, from the ve≈ø≈øels at our wharves, the American pe≈øtilence would have become
epidemic, in our city, in either of the years, to which I have alluded. I have even gone ≈øo far as to flatter my≈øelf, with a belief, that, in the pre≈øent ≈øtate of our city, ≈øuch co-operation is ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary to its epidemic prevalence. In this belief, however, I am, by no means, confirmed. Perhaps, even now, the filth of our city and ≈øuburbs has accumulated to a ≈øufficient height, to give to pe≈øtilence an epidemic rage. In ninety three, I had not completed my medical ≈øtudies, and can, therefore, ≈øay nothing re≈øpecting the immediate ≈øource of particular ca≈øes, that might have occurred in the city during that year. But I he≈øitate not to ≈øay, with as much confidence, as I ought to u≈øe, in ≈øpeaking on any ≈øpeculative ≈øubject in phy≈øics, that, in ninety ≈øeven and ninety eight, I ≈øaw, my≈øelf, ≈øeveral ca≈øes of the di≈øea≈øe in que≈øtion, which mu≈øt have nece≈ø≈øarily re≈øulted from the operation of dome≈øtic cau≈øes. I am further confident, that many ca≈øes of a ≈øimilar nature, were attended by ≈øome of my medical friends. If, then, from the pre≈øent ≈øources of our city, ≈øolitary, or (to ≈øpeak in medical language) ≈øporadic ca≈øes of pe≈øtilence may now occur, how melancholy is our pro≈øpect, ≈øhould the filth in our city and ≈øuburbs, be ≈øuffered to accumulate with the progre≈øs of time! But let us, even, for a moment, admit, that not a ≈øingle ca≈øe „Äà‚óä„Äâ the epidemics of ninety three, ninety ≈øeven, or ninety eight, originated from the exclu≈øive operation of dome≈øtic cau≈øes. Still, it is a po≈øition, which no one will venture
to deny, that their rapid and exten≈øive propagation, was effected by ≈øome peculiarity in the atmo≈øphere of our city. This inference we draw from the very few in≈øtances, in which, the pe≈øtilence, under con≈øideration, was propagated by contagion when taken from the city to the unadulterated atmo≈øphere of the country.

Were the atmo≈øphere of Philadelphia pre≈øerved in purity, by a due degree of attention to dome≈øtic cleanline≈øs, and by preventing ve≈ø≈øels, charged with foul air, from entering our port, pe≈øtilence, as an epidemic, would never again occur, to ≈øwell the catalogue of our future misfortunes.‚Äî In ≈øuch a ≈øtate of things, ≈øporadic ca≈øes of the di≈øea≈øe might, possibly, originate with our≈øelves, and might, unque≈øtionably, be introduced from di≈øtant places; but the evil would terminate with the death or recovery of tho≈øe fir≈øt attacked, and would never ≈øpread, to the di≈øtre≈øs of our citizens, and the depopulation of our city. III. Thus, whatever principles, I may advocate, with re≈øpect to the practicability of pe≈øtilence originating and exi≈øting, as an epidemic, in our city, under certain circum≈øtances, from the exclu≈øive operation of dome≈øtic cau≈øes, I believe this to be an event, which has never yet occurred, Commerce appears to have been, at all times, ju≈øtly chargeable with part of the calamity, that has never failed, to accompany this wor≈øt of evils. of the ≈øummer-≈øun on the filth of our city and ≈øuburbs, while immen≈øe volumes of foul air, di≈øcharged from the holds of ve≈ø≈øels at our wharves, ≈øerved as the ≈øpark to rou≈øe it into flame. Had not the train exi≈øted, the ≈øpark would have expired without effect, and had not the ≈øpark been applied, the train would have lain dormant, and, perhaps never bur≈øt into actual explo≈øion‚ÄîIf, then, by the de≈øtruction of either of the≈øe, we might acquire an exemption from the inevitable effects of their co-operation, by the removal of the one, and the prevention of the other, we become doubly ≈øecure again≈øt the calamities, to which they give origin.

I hope I will be indulged in attempting, by another analogy, a farther illu≈øtration of the above intricate and intere≈øting ≈øubject. With this view, I would compare the ≈øummer atmo≈øphere of our city, deeply contaminated by putrid exhalations from dome≈øtic ≈øources, to a ma≈øs of pa≈øte or dough, duly kneaded, and prepared to undergo the proce≈øs of fermentation. In this ≈øtate of things, the yea≈øt, or leven, calculated and intended to give actual birth to this proce≈øs, not unfitly repre≈øents the foul air i≈ø≈øuing from the holds of ve≈ø≈øels at our wharves, and mixing, in abundance, with our vitiated atmo≈øphere. As the operation of the ferment is well known to be, that of a≈ø≈øimilating to it≈øelf, the ma≈øs into which it is introduced, ≈øuch would ≈øeem to be the effect of the deleterious air di≈øcharged along our wharves. It communicates to the atmo≈øphere of our city, perhaps, by a peculiar ≈øpecies of fermentation, its own pe≈øtilential and
de≈øtructive properties. Or, like the matter of the ≈ømallpox, introduced into a ≈øy≈øtem predi≈øpo≈øed to its reception, it inoculates our atmo≈øphere with effect, and thus, possibly, by an inde≈øcribable ≈øpecies of ≈øympathetic action, approximates to its own nature, the air that ≈øurrounds us.

If we pay due attention to all the branches of dome≈øtic cleanline≈øs, and keep foul ve≈ø≈øels at a di≈øtance from our wharves, war may rage in the We≈øt-Indies,Of all the explications, which have been hitherto given for the exi≈øtence of our late epidemics, none has appeared to me, ≈øo completely the child of fancy, as that, which attributes it to the prevalence of war in the We≈øt Indies. Whereas, on the other hand, if the≈øe requi≈øites be not attended to,‚Äîif our city and ≈øuburbs be ≈øuffered to continue immer≈øed in their pre≈øent filth, and ve≈ø≈øels be allowed to di≈øembogue their pe≈øtilential vapours along our wharves, though the We≈øt Indies ≈øhould be converted into an Eden of peace, fragrance, and healthfulne≈øs, and though the ≈øeeds of pe≈øtilence, ≈øhould be, for ever, bla≈øted along the ≈øhores of A≈øia, and Africa, yet ≈øtill, will Philadelphia‚Äîhaple≈øs Philadelphia, remain ≈øubject to a reiteration of the melancholy ≈øcenes of ninety three, ninety ≈øeven, and ninety eight!

div.head: A SEMI-ANNUAL ORATION, &c.
div.p: IN ri≈øing to addre≈øs you on the pre≈øent occa≈øions my feelings impel me to a two-fold acknowledgment‚ÄîAn acknowledgment for the unexpected honour, with which I have been di≈øtingui≈øhed, in your appointing me to prepare and deliver the fir≈øt of the ≈øemiannual addre≈ø≈øes enjoined by our con≈øtitution; and a mo≈øt cordial acknowledgment for the liberal indulgence, which I experienced from you, on a former occa≈øion, when indi≈øpo≈øition interfered, and, by fru≈øtrating my attempt to comply with my engagement, di≈øappointed, for the time, the expectations of the Academy.

But ≈øati≈øfied that I have more‚Äîmuch more, to expect from the ingenuous liberality of your minds, than from the humble merit of my own defence, I will no longer addre≈øs you in the language of apology. It was my intention to have paid in this place, a pa≈ø≈øing tribute to the memory of our two decea≈øed friends and fellow-members, Dr. Sayre and Dr. Cooper. I had even prepared
my≈øelf for the di≈øcharge of this mournful duty. It is, in this place, worthy of remark, that Pestilence has been, at all times, treated by the world, as an illigitimate child, without an acknowledged parent‚Äîin other words, as a plant perfectly exotic as to every inhabited ≈øoil and climate‚Äîor as a phy≈øical evil, exi≈øting in almo≈øt every region, yet (≈øtrange incon≈øi≈øtency!) originating in none!

It is a fact not more ≈øingular than true, that, there is not to be found in the whole range of the globe, a ≈øingle country, which is acknowledged by its own inhabitants, to be the immediate birth-place of pe≈øtilence. To you, Gentlemen, it is ≈øcarcely nece≈ø≈øary for me to ob≈øerve, that this unwillingne≈øs in mankind to acknowledge pe≈øtilence to be a native of the ≈øame country with them≈øelves, ≈øhould be viewed as an inveterate prejudice, ≈øupported,

Taking the ≈øentiments of mankind, on this ≈øubject, for our guide, we would find a ≈øearch after the real birth-place of pe≈øtilence equally abortive with the poet's ≈øearch after the North, which he ≈øo energetically repre≈øents in the following lines.

Were not the ≈øubject too ≈øerious to be treated as a je≈øt, I would farther ≈øay, that this ≈øingular ab≈øurdity, in mo≈øt men, with re≈øpect to the birth-place of pe≈øtilence, brings to my recollection the humourous ≈øtory of Gold≈ømith's pauper, who, in que≈øt of the real or acknowledged place of his birth,
